metadata.title: Mapping British North America
metadata.author: Danielle DeVantier
metadata.subtitle: European and Indigenous Presences Mapped in the Late 18th Century

caption.text: This map was created by Herman Moll, a cartographer and engraver based out of London.
This map was created by Richard William Seale, an English cartographer and engraver who was also based out of London. John Hinton, a British bookseller and publisher, also contributed to this map.

These two maps are both products of British cartographers, but they depict British North America slightly differently. Moll’s map is much more decorative than Seale’s interpretation of North America. Moll's map is also much larger, measuring 100 x 60 centimeters, while Seale's is only 25 x 33 centimeters.
Moll dedicated this map to "Walter Dowglass." Colonel Walter Douglas was the governor of the British colony on the Leeward Islands.
caption.title: The Dedication

caption.text: This British coat of arms from the Douglas family emphasizes the claims Europeans created to lands in the Americas. The outreaching arm with a sword captures that sense of power Europeans attempted to wield over land and people.
Seale did not dedicate this map to anyone, but Hinton chose to include it in the twenty-eighth volume of the *Universal Magazine of Knowledge and Pleasure* that he published in 1761.
caption.title: The Cartouche

caption.text: The cartouche on this map depicts beavers building a dam in Canada near Niagara Falls. It's interesting to note that the mapmaker chose to illustrate the lands of North America without Indigenous peoples or Europeans, making it seem that North America was an uninhabited wilderness prior to European arrival.

Moll includes a key for miles in his map, while Seale does not. This key also displays a relationship between Britain and France as two colonial powers in the Americas and their proximity to one another as they competed for land and resources.

Both maps include how many degrees away the North American colonies were from London. This may signal to the allegiances of the map makers to Imperial Britain, but also that London was commonly used as the prime meridian in historical maps.
caption.title: Distance from London

caption.text: Like Moll, Seale highlights his European map making skills by using London as the prime meridian. It was common for British and other European cartographers to use the London prime meridian to help viewers comprehend the distance of the places on maps.
Moll's map is much larger, signaling to its use as a decorative piece. The map is busy with text and it is difficult to navigate the space due to the amount of information.
caption.title: Information Organization

caption.text: This map is more legible as it does not include information besides the names of places and groups of peoples. The colonial and Indigenous powers present in North America are more easily known in this map.

Moll exhibits great detail in his map, including smaller maps in the lower portion of the map to highlight the colonies in the Carolinas, Louisiana, and Florida. He also includes a zoomed out map of North America which shows the colonial powers present in New Spain, New France, and New Britain. The southern focus on this colonial map may have been included to show the proximity of power to Governor Douglas in the Leeward Islands.

Seale depicts British North America much simpler than Moll. This map is less busy, has less writing in the margins, and less decorative items. This map was a decorative illustration in a published periodical, not a large piece for display, which may be why it's more simple in text and decoration.
Both maps include the names of Indigenous peoples that Europeans had come into contact with as they colonized North America.
caption.title: Indigenous Presences on the Maps

caption.text: Moll includes the Iroquois, known as the Haudenosaunee or Six Nations, on his map of North America. He includes text describing the governance structure of the Haudenosaunee in European terms and how the Indigenous peoples may have served the British. Including the Haudenosaunee on the map negates the European myth that the New World was empty and untouched.

Seale also acknowledges the Haudenosaunee presence in the western part of what is now New York. He labels them as the "Confederate Indians," referencing the French-given name of the Iroquois Confederacy.

Seale labels different groups of Indigenous peoples, signaling an understanding of the diversity amongst nations. He does not include other information about these peoples like Moll, just labeling them as "Algonquins" or the "Northern Iroquois."

In the map inset of the Carolina region, the presence of Indigenous people is labeled simply as "Indian Settlements," with the exception of the Cayaweh settlement, referencing the Kiawah who lived near the coast of what is now South Carolina.
The presence of Indigenous peoples is once again acknowledged, but clarifying their relation to English power. "Taogaria" and "Chereckes" may refer to the Cherokee in what is now Tennessee.

Descriptions of Indigenous peoples as either "a subtile nation" or "a fiery people" reveal how Europeans viewed Indigenous nations. Europeans may have trivialized Indigenous identity with labels such as these.

Indigenous peoples' place within the maps seems to be at the edge of New England, the so thought hub of civilization at the time. There is not much detail west of the Haudenosaunee making it seem that Indigenous peoples were far removed from English settlements. Europeans would have been closer to Indigenous peoples and created the displacement of Indigenous nations as they settled on their lands.

Maps have the ability to enforce colonial narratives of imperialism and power relations. In British North America the power struggle for land between Britain and Indigenous peoples is evident by the way the British depict space, placement, and names of Indigenous and European settlements.
